Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: How does this work of art make you feel? Feedback example: Let’s avoid the words “good” and “bad” in expressing since normative judgments are premature at this point.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: And the orange thing is the cloud.What’s going on? Feedback example: Let’s begin with general statements of obvious thematic content and then work to the specifics of detail and form.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What strikes you as formally significant in the work? Feedback example: Art works are all of a piece. There are no parts in an artwork that do not count, all forms and relationships have expressive significance. So let’s attempt to impart meaning to these forms in the same holistic spirit in which they were constructed.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: They look like zooming fireballs. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: What do you think this work means? Feedback example: Every interpretive statement should be guided by the fully developed driving pervasive quality and funded by the objective visual facts contained within the work. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.
Contextual Examination: Step explanation: Provides added perspective on the circumstances of the work (who, what, when, where, why, and how surrounding the work). Contextual description is focused on the artist’s life and intentions; the circumstances of the making of the work; the function or the functions of the work; and its place in society—its symbolic meanings, its reflection of beliefs, and so on. If a work is remote to students either culturally or in time, it may be better to start with the contextual examination. Questioning example: Who did the work? Feedback example: Let’s find the information about the work, social, political, religious, and economic nature of the artist’s world and how these factors influence the artist’s role in that world.
Synthesis_Resolution: Step explanation: Resolving personal or interactively developed interpretations with those of the experts as determined in the contextual examination. Students who can substantiate an argument for meaning that runs counter to the experts’, or even the artist’s, and can point to visual evidence, must be respected for their positions. This is an appropriate time for a teacher to introduce aesthetic theory, in this case, issues revolving around artistic intentionalism. Questioning example: Is artist the final word on meaning in artworks? Feedback example: You can briefly restate personal interpretations, and then salient points of expert opinion. The next operation is to try to reconcile personal and expert views by discussing how you agree or overlap and to note where you disagree.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: What was the quality of your experience in critiquing this work? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: How does this work of art make you feel? Feedback example: That’s very good.

Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.

Synthesis_Resolution: Step explanation: Resolving personal or interactively developed interpretations with those of the experts as determined in the contextual examination. Students who can substantiate an argument for meaning that runs counter to the experts’, or even the artist’s, and can point to visual evidence, must be respected for their positions. This is an appropriate time for a teacher to introduce aesthetic theory, in this case, issues revolving around artistic intentionalism. Questioning example: Is artist the final word on meaning in artworks? Feedback example: It’s perfectly acceptable for the viewer to disagree with expert opinion at this point.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: What was the quality of your experience in critiquing this work? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Have your perceptions or feelings changed since we started? How? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: What do you think about what you see? Feedback example: Let’s avoid the words “good” and “bad” in expressing since normative judgments are premature at this point.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: And the orange thing is the cloud.What’s going on? Feedback example: Yes, they look like they are fighting, but no it’s not a crab and it’s not a raccoon. Can you guess it again?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What strikes you as formally significant in the work? Feedback example: What feelings does it evoke?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: They look like zooming fireballs. Questioning example: Is the work calmly symmetrical or actively asymmetrical? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: If you are inside the work, as a particular character, abstract form, or figure, what would you be thinking and feeling? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.
Contextual Examination: Step explanation: Provides added perspective on the circumstances of the work (who, what, when, where, why, and how surrounding the work). Contextual description is focused on the artist’s life and intentions; the circumstances of the making of the work; the function or the functions of the work; and its place in society—its symbolic meanings, its reflection of beliefs, and so on. If a work is remote to students either culturally or in time, it may be better to start with the contextual examination. Questioning example: What materials were available to the artist? Feedback example: Let’s find the information about the work, social, political, religious, and economic nature of the artist’s world and how these factors influence the artist’s role in that world.
Synthesis_Resolution: Step explanation: Resolving personal or interactively developed interpretations with those of the experts as determined in the contextual examination. Students who can substantiate an argument for meaning that runs counter to the experts’, or even the artist’s, and can point to visual evidence, must be respected for their positions. This is an appropriate time for a teacher to introduce aesthetic theory, in this case, issues revolving around artistic intentionalism. Questioning example: What is there about this work that is significant to me, and why? Feedback example: You can briefly restate personal interpretations, and then salient points of expert opinion. The next operation is to try to reconcile personal and expert views by discussing how you agree or overlap and to note where you disagree.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Have your perceptions or feelings changed since we started? How? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: What do you think about what you see? Feedback example: That’s very good.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: What images(illusions, pictures of recognizable things) do you see? Feedback example: Let’s begin with general statements of obvious thematic content and then work to the specifics of detail and form.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What strikes you as formally significant in the work? Feedback example: What is the effect?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: They look like zooming fireballs. Questioning example: What mood is presented? How are we meant to feel in the presence of this piece? Why? What’s the evidence? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: If you are inside the work, as a particular character, abstract form, or figure, what would you be thinking and feeling? Feedback example: Make a claim about your topic: Claim – An explanation or interpretation of some aspect of the artwork
Contextual Examination: Step explanation: Provides added perspective on the circumstances of the work (who, what, when, where, why, and how surrounding the work). Contextual description is focused on the artist’s life and intentions; the circumstances of the making of the work; the function or the functions of the work; and its place in society—its symbolic meanings, its reflection of beliefs, and so on. If a work is remote to students either culturally or in time, it may be better to start with the contextual examination. Questioning example: What were the basic artistic assumptions and restrictions? Feedback example: Let’s find the information about the work, social, political, religious, and economic nature of the artist’s world and how these factors influence the artist’s role in that world.
Synthesis_Resolution: Step explanation: Resolving personal or interactively developed interpretations with those of the experts as determined in the contextual examination. Students who can substantiate an argument for meaning that runs counter to the experts’, or even the artist’s, and can point to visual evidence, must be respected for their positions. This is an appropriate time for a teacher to introduce aesthetic theory, in this case, issues revolving around artistic intentionalism. Questioning example: What is there about this work that is significant to me, and why? Feedback example: It’s perfectly acceptable for the viewer to disagree with expert opinion at this point.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Is there any difference after appreciating this art? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: What do you think about what you see? Feedback example: Where (or what) did you see that made you think that?
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: What images(illusions, pictures of recognizable things) do you see? Feedback example: If the work is very abstract, it is better to venture a guess than to describe it as having no denotative content.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What(colors, shapes, textures, lines) dominate the image? Why? Feedback example: Art works are all of a piece. There are no parts in an artwork that do not count, all forms and relationships have expressive significance. So let’s attempt to impart meaning to these forms in the same holistic spirit in which they were constructed.

Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.

Contextual Examination: Step explanation: Provides added perspective on the circumstances of the work (who, what, when, where, why, and how surrounding the work). Contextual description is focused on the artist’s life and intentions; the circumstances of the making of the work; the function or the functions of the work; and its place in society—its symbolic meanings, its reflection of beliefs, and so on. If a work is remote to students either culturally or in time, it may be better to start with the contextual examination. Questioning example: What does the work tell us about the people who made and used it? Feedback example: Let’s find the information about the work, social, political, religious, and economic nature of the artist’s world and how these factors influence the artist’s role in that world.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Do you feel a need to resolve what you found through personal critique with what you found in the contextual examination? Can this be done? If so, how? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: What’s your first response to this work? Feedback example: That’s very good.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: What images(illusions, pictures of recognizable things) do you see? Feedback example: Yes, they look like they are fighting, but no it’s not a crab and it’s not a raccoon. Can you guess it again?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What(colors, shapes, textures, lines) dominate the image? Why? Feedback example: You can use visual concepts such as proximity, similarity, direction, closure, motion, and implied motion. See if it fits the situation.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: They look like zooming fireballs. Questioning example: Is this work realistic? Formalistic? Expressionistic? Some combination? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: Can you explain this picture in detail to your family when you return home today?
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Do you feel a need to resolve what you found through personal critique with what you found in the contextual examination? Can this be done? If so, how? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Wow! That’s bright! Makes me think of the Big Apple. Questioning example: What’s your first response to this work? Feedback example: Where (or what) did you see that made you think that?

Questioning example: What colors(shapes, textures, lines, etc.) do you see? Feedback example: Let’s begin with general statements of obvious thematic content and then work to the specifics of detail and form.

Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Feedback example: What feelings does it evoke?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: They look like zooming fireballs. Questioning example: To which stylistic category does this work belong? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: What title would you give this work if you were the artist? Why? Feedback example: Every interpretive statement should be guided by the fully developed driving pervasive quality and funded by the objective visual facts contained within the work. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Is the work well made? Do you think its form, composition, and technique are good? Why or why not? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Questioning example: What’s your first response to this work? Feedback example: It's impressive how well you express your feelings in writing.

Questioning example: To which stylistic category does this work belong? Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.

Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: Are there significant negative areas or spaces in the work? What makes them significant? Feedback example: Art works are all of a piece. There are no parts in an artwork that do not count, all forms and relationships have expressive significance. So let’s attempt to impart meaning to these forms in the same holistic spirit in which they were constructed.

If this artwork is the middle of a story, what might have happened before? If this artwork is the end of a story, what might the story be? Feedback example: Make a claim about your topic: Claim – An explanation or interpretation of some aspect of the artwork
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Can a judgment of the work also be extended to the social realm? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Hmmm. I don’t get much from that. Kind of blah. Questioning example: What do you see? Feedback example: Let’s avoid the words “good” and “bad” in expressing since normative judgments are premature at this point.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: Are there any outstanding or unusual features you notice? Feedback example: If the work is very abstract, it is better to venture a guess than to describe it as having no denotative content.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: Are there significant negative areas or spaces in the work? What makes them significant? Feedback example: What feelings does it evoke?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: They look like zooming fireballs. Questioning example: What if this work were realistic instead of having exaggerated forms? What if it had soft instead of hard edges? Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: If this artwork is the beginning of a story, what might happen next? If this artwork is the middle of a story, what might have happened before? If this artwork is the end of a story, what might the story be? Feedback example: Identify support for your claim: Support – Thing you see, feel and know about your claim
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Can a judgment of the work also be extended to the social realm? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What movement do you see? What elements(line, shape, etc.) and principles(rhythm, proportion, etc.) cause movement? Feedback example: Art works are all of a piece. There are no parts in an artwork that do not count, all forms and relationships have expressive significance. So let’s attempt to impart meaning to these forms in the same holistic spirit in which they were constructed.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like blasting heads of fire. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: It was the artist’s attempt to make a picture of a twisty, a tangled rainbow. Questioning example: What would it be like to be sitting on the hillside shown in this painting? Feedback example: Every interpretive statement should be guided by the fully developed driving pervasive quality and funded by the objective visual facts contained within the work. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Hmmm. I don’t get much from that. Kind of blah. Questioning example: What do you wonder about? Feedback example: It's impressive how well you express your feelings in writing.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: Are there any dark(light) areas? Rough or unusual textures? Large or small shapes? And so on… Feedback example: What do you see that makes you say that?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What movement do you see? What elements(line, shape, etc.) and principles(rhythm, proportion, etc.) cause movement? Feedback example: What is the effect?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like blasting heads of fire. Questioning example: What mood is presented? How are we meant to feel in the presence of this piece? Why? What’s the evidence? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: If I have to name it, I will call it ‘A Silly Picture’ Questioning example: What do you think this work means? Feedback example: Make a claim about your topic: Claim – An explanation or interpretation of some aspect of the artwork
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: How does the work reflect life forces, social themes, and causes and sensibilities of its times? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: Hmmm. I don’t get much from that. Kind of blah. Questioning example: What’s your first response to this work? Feedback example: Let’s avoid the words “good” and “bad” in expressing since normative judgments are premature at this point.

Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: Where do you see contrast? What causes it? Feedback example: Art works are all of a piece. There are no parts in an artwork that do not count, all forms and relationships have expressive significance. So let’s attempt to impart meaning to these forms in the same holistic spirit in which they were constructed.

Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like blasting heads of fire. Questioning example: To which stylistic category does this work belong? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: If I have to name it, I will call it ‘A Silly Picture’ Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: How perceptions and attached values may have been changed or strengthened during the process? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It’s big. Questioning example: How does this work of art make you feel? Feedback example: It's impressive how well you express your feelings in writing.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: How do you think this work was made? a painting? a sculpture? a photograph? something else? Feedback example: Look at the image quietly for at least 30 seconds. And list 10 words or phrases about any aspect of the picture.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What are the figures looking/leaning towards/pointing? Feedback example: You don’t have to look for every formal quality randomly and exhaustively, but only for those most salient clues suggested by interest.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like blasting heads of fire. Questioning example: Would you characterize it as primitive, slick, aggressive, bold, intellectual, overpowering, timid, monumental, fluid, abstract, cool, static, rhythmic, hot, etc.? Why? What’s the evidence? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: If I have to name it, I will call it ‘A Silly Picture’ Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: Make a claim about your topic: Claim – An explanation or interpretation of some aspect of the artwork
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Stylistically, does it feel proficient? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It’s big. Questioning example: What do you see? Feedback example: Let’s avoid the words “good” and “bad” in expressing since normative judgments are premature at this point.

Feedback example: Let’s focus on seeing the pattern, then to see its parts and how they contribute to the whole and ultimately to the thematic content and overall expressive purpose of the work.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.

Feedback example: Identify support for your claim: Support – Thing you see, feel and know about your claim
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Stylistically, does it feel proficient? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.

It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Is the best commercial poster as good as the best “fine” art? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It’s big. Questioning example: What do you wonder about? Feedback example: Where (or what) did you see that made you think that?
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: Why do you think so? What types of brush strokes(sculptural finish, photographic technique, etc.) do you see? Feedback example: Yes, they look like they are fighting, but no it’s not a crab and it’s not a raccoon. Can you guess it again?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What is the focal point in this work? What causes you to look there? Feedback example: Let’s focus on seeing the pattern, then to see its parts and how they contribute to the whole and ultimately to the thematic content and overall expressive purpose of the work.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like syncopated light blips moving in a gridlock, setting the stage very well for mature interpretation. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: If I have to name it, I will call it ‘A Silly Picture’ Questioning example: If this artwork is the beginning of a story, what might happen next? If this artwork is the middle of a story, what might have happened before? If this artwork is the end of a story, what might the story be? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It feels sterile, it reminds me of Indiana. Questioning example: How does this work of art make you feel? Feedback example: That’s very good.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: This is a picture of birds and fish metamorphosing into each other. Questioning example: What can you say is the characteristic of this work? Feedback example: If the work is very abstract, it is better to venture a guess than to describe it as having no denotative content.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What are its parts? Feedback example: Let’s look for formal units which are distinguishable from one another but which all belong together in some larger sense.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like syncopated light blips moving in a gridlock, setting the stage very well for mature interpretation. Questioning example: Why are we meant to focus where we do? Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I think the women in the painting are waiting for the boss. Maybe the boss told them to sit there and maybe he's walking Questioning example: What do you think this work means? Feedback example: Let’s use as rich and as fully developed language as you have to convey the mature emotional and cognitive meaning evoked by the work.

Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a sun with reddish and black. Questioning example: And the orange thing is the cloud.What’s going on? Feedback example: What do you see that makes you say that?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What are its pieces, components? Feedback example: How about using comparison and contrast.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like syncopated light blips moving in a gridlock, setting the stage very well for mature interpretation. Questioning example: What if the background were a different color? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I think the women in the painting are waiting for the boss. Maybe the boss told them to sit there and maybe he's walking Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: Every interpretive statement should be guided by the fully developed driving pervasive quality and funded by the objective visual facts contained within the work. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: What is the work’s driving pervasive quality? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It feels sterile, it reminds me of Indiana. Questioning example: What do you wonder about? Feedback example: That’s very good.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a sun with reddish and black. Questioning example: And the orange thing is the cloud.What’s going on? Feedback example: What more can you find?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What are its pieces, components? Feedback example: Let’s use principles of design such as unity, variety, balance, and so on, as conceptual tools giving clues about significance in the work.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It looks like syncopated light blips moving in a gridlock, setting the stage very well for mature interpretation. Questioning example: What if the background were a different color? Feedback example: Stylistic categorizations may be broad as realist, formalist, expressionist, fantastic, and instrumental, or as specific as Abstract Expressionism, Process Art, or Impressionism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I think the women in the painting are waiting for the boss. Maybe the boss told them to sit there and maybe he's walking Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: Let’s use as rich and as fully developed language as you have to convey the mature emotional and cognitive meaning evoked by the work.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: What is the work’s driving pervasive quality? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It feels sterile, it reminds me of Indiana. Questioning example: What’s your first response to this work? Feedback example: Where (or what) did you see that made you think that?
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a sun with reddish and black. Questioning example: What images(illusions, pictures of recognizable things) do you see? Feedback example: Let’s begin with general statements of obvious thematic content and then work to the specifics of detail and form.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What can you say is the characteristic of this work? Feedback example: Art works are all of a piece. There are no parts in an artwork that do not count, all forms and relationships have expressive significance. So let’s attempt to impart meaning to these forms in the same holistic spirit in which they were constructed.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It swings and moves and jerks and stops like dancing. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.

Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a bad painting because you just can’t figure out what it looks like. Questioning example: Does it seem “right” in terms of color, composition, and so on? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a sun with reddish and black. Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What can you say is the characteristic of this work? Feedback example: Good analytic tools to apply at this stage are the principles of design. You can try each one on to see if it fits, and how, and why.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It swings and moves and jerks and stops like dancing. Questioning example: Is the work calmly symmetrical or actively asymmetrical? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.

Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a sun with reddish and black. Questioning example: What colors(shapes, textures, lines, etc.) do you see? Feedback example: Yes, they look like they are fighting, but no it’s not a crab and it’s not a raccoon. Can you guess it again?
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Analysis: Step explanation: Look for formal relationships between forms and images. Differences such as changes in rhythm or one thing’s being bigger, darker, brighter than another are particularly significant clues for meaning. Focus on principles of design: unity, variety, focus, rhythm and so on. Questioning example: What is the largest and the smallest thing that you can see in this painting? Feedback example: You can use visual concepts such as proximity, similarity, direction, closure, motion, and implied motion. See if it fits the situation.
Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: It swings and moves and jerks and stops like dancing. Questioning example: Is this work realistic? Formalistic? Expressionistic? Some combination? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I think the women in the painting are waiting for the boss. Maybe the boss told them to sit there and maybe he's walking Questioning example: What would it be like to be sitting on the hillside shown in this painting? Feedback example: Can you explain this picture in detail to your family when you return home today?
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting because you can see that the artist used different colors and stuff. Questioning example: Have your perceptions or feelings changed since we started? How? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: The lobster is painted with definite long strokes of paint, whereas the cat is painted with squiggly strokes. The lobster looks strong because it is very angular and geometric, metallic and robotic. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: Maybe the artist thought it would look neat and we’d really like it and stuff. Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: Every interpretive statement should be guided by the fully developed driving pervasive quality and funded by the objective visual facts contained within the work. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting because you can see that the artist used different colors and stuff. Questioning example: Does it clearly express a point of view? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It’s pretty. Questioning example: How does this work of art make you feel? Feedback example: That’s very good.

Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: The lobster is painted with definite long strokes of paint, whereas the cat is painted with squiggly strokes. The lobster looks strong because it is very angular and geometric, metallic and robotic. Questioning example: What if the background were a different color? Feedback example: Why did you think so?

Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: The artist has placed the cat backing off the canvas. The expression on its face is frightened. The lobster takes up more space on the canvas. Its diagonal direction of attack is more forceful than the cat’s position of retreat. Questioning example: What is the intended impact of the formal analysis on your emotions? Feedback example: You can use metaphor, mimesis, and anthropomorphism.
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I can see that when he makes his painting it’s like a puzzle. It’s like a mystery you have to try and find what he put in. I think that his pitchers are real pure and like pure water. I think that he sees two halves, the first is bright and colorful and the second is dreary but ok. Questioning example: If you are inside the work, as a particular character, abstract form, or figure, what would you be thinking and feeling? Feedback example: Every interpretive statement should be guided by the fully developed driving pervasive quality and funded by the objective visual facts contained within the work. Check your interpretation is based on visual properties.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Perceptual Analysis_Formal Characterizat: Step explanation: Intended impact of the forms, colors, theme, and their relationships. Characterize the formal qualities. This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: The artist has placed the cat backing off the canvas. The expression on its face is frightened. The lobster takes up more space on the canvas. Its diagonal direction of attack is more forceful than the cat’s position of retreat. Questioning example: Is the work calmly symmetrical or actively asymmetrical? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I can see that when he makes his painting it’s like a puzzle. It’s like a mystery you have to try and find what he put in. I think that his pitchers are real pure and like pure water. I think that he sees two halves, the first is bright and colorful and the second is dreary but ok. Questioning example: What does it remind you of and make you think of? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting because you can see that the artist used different colors and stuff. Questioning example: Compositionally, does it hold together? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Reaction: Step explanation: Initial, general, global, intuitive, evaluative response. Utterance example: It’s ugly. Questioning example: What do you wonder about? Feedback example: It's impressive how well you express your feelings in writing.
Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a sun with reddish and black. Questioning example: What can you say is the characteristic of this work? Feedback example: Look at the image quietly for at least 30 seconds. And list 10 words or phrases about any aspect of the picture.

This is a combination of analysis and creative projection and serves as a bridge to interpretation. Utterance example: The artist has placed the cat backing off the canvas. The expression on its face is frightened. The lobster takes up more space on the canvas. Its diagonal direction of attack is more forceful than the cat’s position of retreat. Questioning example: To which stylistic category does this work belong? Feedback example: Why did you think so?
Personal Interpretation: Step explanation: Interpretation brings personal associative experience that analyzing content, form, and character, to find out intentional meaning beyond surface. Interpretation tells us what the object means, answering the question; what is this work all about? Since interpretation is creative activity, multiple interpretations should be included in interactive educational critiques. Utterance example: I can see that when he makes his painting it’s like a puzzle. It’s like a mystery you have to try and find what he put in. I think that his pitchers are real pure and like pure water. I think that he sees two halves, the first is bright and colorful and the second is dreary but ok. Questioning example: If this artwork is the beginning of a story, what might happen next? If this artwork is the middle of a story, what might have happened before? If this artwork is the end of a story, what might the story be? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting because you can see that the artist used different colors and stuff. Questioning example: Finally, does it move you? Does it have the aesthetic power to make you feel something strongly, or think something new, or move you to action in any way? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Questioning example: How do you think this work was made? a painting? a sculpture? a photograph? something else? Feedback example: What do you see that makes you say that?
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting. You can see better because it’s outlined. It’s kind of blurry. Questioning example: Would you like to own this work? Why or why not? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: It looks like a witch hat with stars on it. Questioning example: What can you say is the characteristic of this work? Feedback example: If the work is very abstract, it is better to venture a guess than to describe it as having no denotative content.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting. You can see better because it’s outlined. It’s kind of blurry. Questioning example: What is the work’s contextual significance? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

They got different kinds of dresses on and there is a mountain. Questioning example: What colors(shapes, textures, lines, etc.) do you see? Feedback example: What more can you find?
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting. You can see better because it’s outlined. It’s kind of blurry. Questioning example: Is the work clear? Does it do what it seems to be trying to do? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting. You can see better because it’s outlined. It’s kind of blurry. Questioning example: Is the work clear? Does it do what it seems to be trying to do? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: There are eight girls sitting on chairs. They got different kinds of dresses on and there is a mountain. Questioning example: What colors(shapes, textures, lines, etc.) do you see? Feedback example: Look at the image quietly for at least 30 seconds. And list 10 words or phrases about any aspect of the picture.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting. You can see better because it’s outlined. It’s kind of blurry. Questioning example: Finally, does it move you? Does it have the aesthetic power to make you feel something strongly, or think something new, or move you to action in any way? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Feedback example: Describe more elaborately about the artwork then me.
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: It’s a good painting. You can see better because it’s outlined. It’s kind of blurry. Questioning example: What do you think about the work? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: Rene Magritte sees the world in a different way than you and I. What other artis would draw a woman in a peach or a man thinking of an apple. Rene Magritte sees the world with a different eye. Questioning example: What was the quality of your experience in critiquing this work? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.
