They got different kinds of dresses on and there is a mountain. Questioning example: What can you say is the characteristic of this work? Feedback example: What more can you find?
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: Rene Magritte sees the world in a different way than you and I. He has more than just an ordinary eye. A mountainside to you and I look like an eagle spreading his wings to him. Only Rene Magritte would draw a painting of a painting of a scene. What other artis would draw a woman in a peach or a man thinking of an apple. Rene Magritte sees the world with a different eye. Questioning example: Does it clearly express a point of view? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: Seems like that could be some kind of bird and then a cloud. Questioning example: And the orange thing is the cloud.What’s going on? Feedback example: Let’s begin with general statements of obvious thematic content and then work to the specifics of detail and form.

Questioning example: Can a judgment of the work also be extended to the social realm? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

He has more than just an ordinary eye. A mountainside to you and I look like an eagle spreading his wings to him. Only Rene Magritte would draw a painting of a painting of a scene. What other artis would draw a woman in a peach or a man thinking of an apple. Rene Magritte sees the world with a different eye. Questioning example: How has the technical handling of the content affected the theme? Feedback example: Your evaluation may include your personal experience, in light of expert opinion, and finally an evaluation of the work in question in light of all that has been learned.

Perceptual Analysis_Representation: Step explanation: Obvious thematic, formal, and technical. Description tells us what an object is and what it is for. Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: Seems like that could be some kind of bird and then a cloud. Questioning example: What colors(shapes, textures, lines, etc.) do you see? Feedback example: What else do you see?

What other artis would draw a woman in a peach or a man thinking of an apple. Rene Magritte sees the world with a different eye. Questioning example: How has the technical handling of the content affected the theme? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Begin with obvious features, such as representational and illusional qualities. Utterance example: Seems like that could be some kind of bird and then a cloud. Questioning example: Are there any dark(light) areas? Rough or unusual textures? Large or small shapes? And so on… Feedback example: Yes, they look like they are fighting, but no it’s not a crab and it’s not a raccoon. Can you guess it again?
Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: Rene Magritte sees the world in a different way than you and I. He has more than just an ordinary eye. A mountainside to you and I look like an eagle spreading his wings to him. Only Rene Magritte would draw a painting of a painting of a scene. What other artis would draw a woman in a peach or a man thinking of an apple. Rene Magritte sees the world with a different eye. Questioning example: Finally, does it move you? Does it have the aesthetic power to make you feel something strongly, or think something new, or move you to action in any way? Feedback example: That’s a really great opinion.

Synthesis_Evaluation: Step explanation: Theories such as formalism, expressionism, mimesis, pragmatism, and conceptualism should be brought to bear on making a summative judgment of an artwork. It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: Rene Magritte has a curious twentieth century view of the world. He is not painting to describe his world but rather to help the viewer feel his world. While his paintings are fairly bold and simplistic,they also are clearly surrealistic. They have a symmetry that is easy to see, but his subject matter haunts the viewer. Magritte’s paintings clearly stretch our imagination to try to capture the unreality of our reality. Questioning example: What was the quality of your experience in critiquing this work? Feedback example: How about making an evaluation of the expressive content of the work in relation to personal and social values.

It is appropriate to evaluate the experience of encountering the work. Evaluation tells us what the object is worth. Utterance example: Rene Magritte has a curious twentieth century view of the world. He is not painting to describe his world but rather to help the viewer feel his world. While his paintings are fairly bold and simplistic,they also are clearly surrealistic. They have a symmetry that is easy to see, but his subject matter haunts the viewer. Magritte’s paintings clearly stretch our imagination to try to capture the unreality of our reality. Questioning example: Can a judgment of the work also be extended to the social realm?
